div.p: This Company's system of submarine telegraph cables is the most direct and quickest means of communication from Egypt to Europe, North and South America, East, South and West Africa, India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency. 31-12-904

div.head: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 7, 1905. f SUEZ CANAL. PROBLEMS.
div.p: The reoent protest entered by certain British shipowners against what they regard as the excessive dues and the arbitrary system of measurements enforced by the Suez Canal Company, and, above all, the bold suggestion to oonstrnct an alternative waterway between the Mediterranean and the Red Sea, lend more than usual interest to the White Paper just issued, dealing with the returns of the Canal for 1904 and the two previous yean. We dealt with the paper from a statist^ point of view in our leading article of Saturday last, but there are other points which deserve fuller consideration in connection with this subjeot. As we stated in Saturday s article, it is more than ever clear that British shipping is the dominating factor in providing the traffio and the reoeipts of the Suez Canal. That fact oertainly lends additional weight to the protests that have been made by an influential group of British ship owners. It has been urged also that the shareholders of the oompany are now reoeiving dividends exceeding 25 per oent per au-num, and that the transit reoeipts for last year, amounting to frs. 115,818,000 or, say, £4,633,000, were the largest on reoord, exceeding those of each of the two previous years respectively by over 12 million francs, and tiiis notwithstanding the foot that in 1903 and 1904 the transit dues have been reduoed from fra. 9 to frs. 8.50 per ton. The obvious deduction is that the oompany could well afford to reduoe its rates considerably further and yet leave ah extremely handsome margin of profit to be divided among its shareholders. This is no doubt true ; but, on the other side, it is contended that the undertaking is a private oompany ; that, as we have seen, the traffio oontinues to increase rapidly, notwithstanding the dues levied, and that even as regards these dues they have been reduced gradually from frs. 12 per ton in 1880 to the present figure of frs. 8.50 per ton. t. Our shippers, or some of them, argue that the time occupied in traversing the Canal is too long, and it is said that as the traffic eases the duration of the passage tends to increase. We are told, indeed. « tue present report that the mean length oftho passage for all vessels navigating the Canal last year was 18 hours 8 minutes, as against 17 hours 48 minutes in 1903; but il we tarn back to earlier reports there does not appear be very muoh in the argument, for in 1902 the average passage took 18 hours 2 minutes, while in 1901 the figures were 18 hours 41 minutes, or over half an hour in »s of those of last year. Even if it oould be shown that the avenge duration of the passage was steadily increasing, that oould hardly be uaed as an argument in favor of the reduction of rates, the natural effect of whioh would be to make the congestion greater. In view, however, of the large increase in revenue last year, i}; appears to us that the time is ripe for the pany to make a further oonoession to shippers in the matter of the dues levied. This it should do in its own interest, so as liminate friotion with its customers aud to prevent those threats of the oonstruotion of a rival undertaking, whioh, however improbable of realisation at present, are pre sumably a source of some disquietude to nervous shareholders. It is a question also, whether, having regard to the rapidly increasing traffic, the time is not approaching when liberal disbursements of capital should made is order to inorease the transport facilities of the Canal and thereby reduce the duration of the passage. It must sot be forgotten, however, that the British Government holds about ll-25ths of the share oapital of the oompany, and that out of 32 directors 10 are British, although the headquarters of the oompany are oertainly in Paris, and it is oonstitntad under Frenoh law. If, therefore, our Government oould be induoed to bring its influence strongly to bear in order to lighten the tax upon the shipping industry, which, of oourse, falls quite as heavily upon foreign ves-as upon those of British nationality, the inevitable redaction of rates might be hasten ed, and some concessions might also be obtained with regard to the system of measurements adopted. FXtal Tram Accident.— A native was killed on Sunday morning by filling under a tram in Old Cairo when attempting to enter it whilst in motion. Death was instantaneous. Hellenic School.—Owing to the prevailing epidemic of diphtheria in Alexandria the viva wee portion of the summer examination now proceeding sit -tho schools of tho Hellenic community of Alexandria will not be held. San- Stefano Casino.—Subscribers of the Casino who desire to attend the instrumental ooncert on Sunday next are asked by tbe management to obtain their subscription cards so as to facilitate the control at tbe entranoe. Is itMurdkrI—The body ot a young native boy was found on Sunday by the Cairo polioe in tbe Khalifa distriot Several wonnds were found on the body Andit was taken to Kasr-el-Aini Hospital for tbe purpose of holding a post mortem examioatioa. French National Fete—The Cairo committee for tho organisation of tbo French national ft to of the 14th July have already, began to take measures for the deooration of tho Esbekieh Gardens, and ths contract for the work has been given oat Judges’ Residences for the Englishmea sppoioted to exercise judicial functions in the Native Coarts at Tiutah, Zagazig, Beni-Soue), Assiout, and Keneh, are to be erected in those towns. Destruction or Crops. - OurMinet el-Kamh Correspondent states that the malevolent destruction of the ootton crop is very prevalent, in spite of the fact that many arrests have been made of persons caught perpetrating thIS'ctf me. A native of Kafr Karmont reported yesterday, that some of his enemies, through personal vengeance, had uprooted about two feddans of cotton belongiag to him, which was nearly all that he possessed. Gruesome Discovert. — At 8.20 p.m. on Sanday, one of the guards of the Egyptian Salt n Soda Company at Mex, on making his usual rounds, noticed a very bad odour proceeding from ofie of the quarry pita On reporting the matter to the director of the salt works, Mr. A C. Ramsay, the latter immediately prooeoded to the spot After procuring a lantern and a rope they there found a body floating face upwards and dressed in European olothes. Tbe oorpee waa in snch a position that it waa diffioalt to ascertain if it was that of a European or not. News of the disoovery was immediately telephoned to the Goavernorat, the police arrived, and, after making out the usual proofs verbal, took the oorpee out at 1 a.m. and transported it to'hospital.

div.head: THE GHIRGEH SCANDAL. ACCUSED ALL ACQUITTED.
div.p: (Bt Telegraph). Assiout, Wednesday, 1 pan. Tbe Moadir of Gbirgeb, Mohamed Bey Ritas, tbe Cadi of the Mehkemeh Shariah, and the other aocused have all been acquitted. PORT OF ALEXANDRIA. Nearly LE 5,000 has already been spent this year oat ot the credits allotted for the improvement of the port of Alexandria. But of the total credit of LE 110,000 opened this year from the General Reserve Fond for the extoqsion of tho import quays, enlargement of Qaay K, an l extension of Qaay J, only LE 115 has been spent Of the credit of LE 38,000 for the extension of the head of the mole, LB. 4,760 has been expended. Only LE 12 has been disbursed of the LE 1,000. voted for studying the Gabbari quays soheme, while if the LE 10,000 for the enlargement of the wuth portion of Quay C nothing has yet been ipent NILE FESTIVAL IN VIENNA. A correspondent, writing from Vienna by last mal, snys: The immense space of the ftotunde was on Satarday filled to overflowing by the mass of people who were present at the great Nde Festival arranged by the Prinoess Paulino Metternioh. One oonld really believe oneself on the banks of tbe Nile at sunsetThe various stalls represented Egyptian shops. Round the stalls the orowd was so great that the help of the police had to be requisitioned in order to keep the people moving. The Prinoess Metternich looked charming in s yellow Egyptian costume. It was covered with gold and silver laoe. On her head tbe princess wore a turban. She went from one itall to the other, sold pictare postcards, and generally did tbe honors in the most charming manner. Countoss Lippe Pallavicini had established \ magnificent art salon where she sold the works of celebrated painters. The picture postcards designed by Countess M. Palffy, which represented the Princess Metternich on k sphinx, had a great suooess. Among those who were bftsy at this stall *ero Princess Engelbert-Auersperg, who looked utreinely well in her Egyptian oostume. Mrs. iL Warndorfer wore a magnificent real Bgyptian costume and looked her very best ia it Another lady in Egyptian oostume was Baroness Prelis-Romerskirch. Countess Nor* Fugger was at the bead of a very well-stocked Egyptian bazaar, and bad bad all the goods sent from Cairo for the occa-lion. With her were Prinoess Alexander Solms, ■rearing a pretty white foulard dress trimmed with light blue; Countess Wurmbrand-Schenk, uountess Frigi Fugger, and Countess Salm-Steinborg. AT THE “AMBASSADEURS.” The open-air musio-hall at Gberireh, which is known by tbe name of “Theatre des Ambas-sadeors,” attracted a large crowd on Satarday evening by advertising a “soiree Veaitienne,” and the many who attended were in no way disappointed. The theatre had been most effectively decorated with festoons of artificial green-leaves and roses, from which were hang maltiooloured electrio-globes,and flags of. every nation were abundant Just before tbe entertainment commenced the audience were somewhat alarmed to see a design of the star and orescent surmounted by a crown, whioh was attached to the left wing of the theatre, oatch fire, and the dames were oertainly considerable. Happily the adjaoent material was not inflammable, for after the alarm had-been raised full five minutes elapsed before any of the officials Attempted to extinguish the fire.No water was available, but eventually the design was detacbed-from its supports and allowed to bum itself out on the ground. The perfonninoe whioh is presented by the management of this theatre is oertainly superior to the average performance witnessed in other Cairo music-halls, and some of the “tarns” were distinctly good. M. Charley, a lightning quick-change artiste, who made his debut in Cairo, was excellent; he portrayed various characters, and the rapidity with whioh he changed his oos-tumes was marvellous. Want of space forbids us to give details of the programme, but the majority of the artistes were worthy of applause. We would, however, suggest to the management that though we appreciate them, we are at the same time somewhat tired of hearing the same artistes over and over again. They would also do well to provide programmes, and, as we suggested before, to so arrange tbe theatre that more than those who are favored with a front seat can witness the various performances.

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID. EUROPEAN DIES FROM PLAGUE.
div.p: (From our Correspondent). Port-Said, Tuesday. The Italian woman, who was isolated three day ago as a plague patient, died yesterday morning and was buried in the afternoon. Tbe case has been officially recognised as plague, and the house in whioh sbo was attacked is being: carefully disinfected. It is a -remarkable fact however, that the customary faneral pro-oession through the principal streets with band aad mourners «v permitted, in spite of the nature of the disease. RUSSIAN VOLUNTEER STEAMER. Ytoterday morning the Volunteer Fleet 8.8. “Nijni Novgorod arrived from the Oanal with numerous Russian wounded on board. It will be remembered that the vessel was one of the first batch to go BaA, in the character then of a transport. NAVAL NOTES H.HB. “Abdel Mouneim” has arrived from Alexandria and is now moored in tbe Rive Asie. She is to proceed to Red 8ea ports in a day or so. H.M.S. "TTietis” sailed yes'.erday at roon for Malta and borne to pay off. 8he has completed her long oommissioo, and on leaving the Etarbour flew her pennant saluting the shore battery as she got out to sea. MINISTRY OF PUBLIC INSTRUCTION. THE 8ECONDARY CERTIFICATE To toe Editor of the Egyptian Gazfttb. Sir,—I have read in the “Gazette” of yesterday your article about the Seoondary Education certificate examination of 1905 and the results therein obtained. My attention has been particularly drawn to your sympathy for the 122 private students of whom only 10 "satisfied the examiners.” As I have been one of the ten private students who by a stroke of luck have “satisfied tbe examiners," I will be much obliged if you will allow me to explain in the “Gazette” tbe reasons for the failure of so many private students. My wish will have been realised if my article is read by the authorities in tbe Ministry of Pablic Instruction. The very small percentage of suooessful private candidates does not imply in any way that private students are of a lower standard than the Government schools' boys. I have known some of them who are by far more learned and bettor prepared than the beit of the Government school boys. Bat the chief and paramount reason tor the failure of so many lies in the etamination questions. The questions are not about the generalities aad essential parts of tbe sabjeot examined in, and the oorreot answers to these quntions do not indicate a real preparation and a good grasp of the subject Tbe questions are drawn from the Government sohool books (some of which may be catch questions), so that the one that does not study in those books, aad does not attend tbe lectnras of tbe Government teachers will very improbably saooeed.even if be has studied in the best books.As an example of this I may say that tEe Government book of physios is an elementary book of about 150 pages ; I studied in a very good English book of physios of 650 pages, but strange to say I was not better off with some of the questions than the least student who bad prepared in that 150 paged book. The Ministry should know that the examination is a publio one open to all schools, consequently the questions should be found in all the boob treating of the subjeot. They should be good and nseful questions whioh any candidate of any sohool can answer, otherwise it will be qoite dear that tbe Ministry does not want anybody to pass the examination exoept those that go to its schools, study in its books, and attend tbe leotures of its own teaoheTs, quite a singular way of unifying eduoation in Egypt The questions in languages were not diffioalt this year, but the stumbling-blook was in the mttbematios. Most of the questions in arithmetic were reasonable but some of the questions in geometry and algebra were very diffioalt Indeed geometry questions have always proved a stumbling block to many, for the reason that they are all original exercises, some of them ot great diffioulty. In other oountries some of the questions in geometry are oo the propositions proved in tbe books taught while others are original onss so that the candidate may be able (if be has really stucUed) to solve soms of them; but when all the questions are original ones tbe student may in bis nervousness not be able to solve any whatever. Another remark on the questions of geo metry and algebra is that the questions should not indude diffioult problems involving long and complicated formulio for the students are notin an engineering sohool; besides, even enguseers themselves are not expected to retain all the formula of •geometry and algebra in their memories. I may also add that the want of leniency oo the part of the examiners .in the oorreotion of the papers is a merciless. crucible, where the hopes of many students are burned and evaporated. If a student understands the arithmetioal problem, and uses tbe right method for its solution, will it be fair not to give him credit for it, if by ohanoe he makes a mistake in addition 'or subtraction of numbers whioh lead to a wrong answer f I beard a very famous mathematician in tbe B»st say that he did not look to the answer of the problem so muoh as to tbe method of its solution, which is the sure m+m. of knowing the ability of the ttndant Sympathising again with ay unhappy oom-redes and thanking you for the space given to my letter.-1 am, efa^ . „ . . “Btoi— in. Put ah 8rrom.” Cain, June i, ltO NOTE8 FROM CYPRUS. HIGH COMMISSIONER’S TOUR (From our Cormkpondent). Cyprus, Jane ?. On the 80th ulto his Exoellency the High Commissioner, accompanied by his Al D. C., Lieut Ogle, left Nioosia on a twelve days' tour in tbe Carpass. If the weather remains fine and not too hot this visit to the N.E part of the Island fhould prove very enjoyable. It will assuredly give muoh pleasure to the inhabitants of that distriot. It is expected that tbe Government will move up to Troodos about the third week in June. x Among tbe English going on leave or returning home this week are the Chief Secretary, Capt A H. Young, C.M.G., and Lady Evelyn Young, Mr. and Mrs. E E Maodonald, Mr. E. F. Lucie Bmith, Mr. und Mrs. Percy Christian and Mrs. Ridings. Colonel Gore will act as Chief Secretary, his duties as Receiver-General being undertaken by tbe Registrar-General, Mr. G. Smith, who will also continue to act as Direotor of Agriculture. Threshing is now in full swing. Reaping machines have been introduoed.of late, but the old method of hand-pulling, or of cutting with a sickle, continnes to prevail. In spite, too, of efforts to make known by practioal experiments the advantages of the threshing tkf threshing floors still hold 'their' own, and tbe primitive threshing boards are herd at work. On and from the 19th ulto. the British postal order system to Cyprus has been extended to include Egypt A law just passed by the Legislative Council to “amend the -law relating to tbe Andent Monuments and Antiquities ol Cyprus and to provide Museums” requires every person in possession of antiquities at the time of the ooming into operation of tbe law to famish a deecriptive list of same to the Government within six months of that data. Any private possession may be oompulsorily inspected from time to time by Government representative, and any antiquities not disdoeed u above may be confiscated by the Government A clause provides that any person failing to prove to the satisfaction of the Court th*t any anti* quity was lawfully acquired by him or that it passed lawfully into his oontrol, «b«ll be liable to a fine not exceeding £50, or to imprison' ment for a term not exceeding six months, or to both each penalties, and the antiquity shall be confiscated. There is probably scarcely a single better-class house in the Island which does not oontain few or many of suoh “antioas.” On the 25th ulto. the first consignment of snow arrived in Nicosia from Mount Troodos. No ioe oo a large soale is obtainable in Cyprus and only a very few small household ioe-suking machines exist For oooling purposes snow is brought daily by carts from Troodos and sdd at 1 j cp. (3d.) per oke. He snow is caoght in pits oo the mountain side and there stored till required for use, bnt the quantity is small and lasts only for a month or two. Owing to the waste in transit it is necessary, to order (and pay for) considerably more than is actually reoeived and oonsumed. Tbe Hospital of Nioosia is entirely dependent upon this means of refrigeration. PERSOnIl AND 80CI/LL, Lord and L*dy Cromer will leave 'Cairo oo 8unday next to embark cn the Bibby Line S.S. ''Lancashire” on Monday at Port Said'. 8ir F. R Wingate Pasha will leave Cairo on Friday for Alexandria, and will embark for the Continent on SitarJay. The Sirdar paid a visit to the military hospital and school at Abhassieh on Monday. R Harman, 2nd Battalion Rifle Brigade, leave* Cairo to-night for Khartoum, for duty there. Lieut G. M. Jennings, 2nd Battalion R. Iiniskilling Fusiliers, hss reoeived an extension of leave, from July 1 to 31. Two months' leave of absenoe has been granted to Mr. C. Among the latest arrivals at tbe Savoy Hotel, Port Said, we notioe: Dr. and Mrs. Wakeling, Mr. Clement Flower, Frau Brandeis, Mr. H. Bindernagd and family, Mr. C. H. div.head: LEGAL NOTES. MIXED APPEAL COURT. raflCENASCB ESTATE.
div.p: Yesterday, before the Mixed Court of Appeal, waa heard the case relating to the division of the property left by the late Baron Moise de Menasoe. Tbe litigants were his daughters, Meedames Lion and Pollooais, bis son Baron lames, sad bis widow Baronees Mode Me-nasce, ntfe Padou. Other interpleaders were the heirs of Baron Elie de Menasoe, and also Messrs. V. and C. Aghion. Tbe oase raised iurious points of international law, and may be summarised in the point of knowing whether the hdr of the owner of an estate is »ntitled to sue in the Mixed Tribunals for a livision of the estate, without first establish-ng in the proper Consoler Court that ho (or n this case she) is entitled, as hdr, to part of £e property. The oase was argued cleverly by tfe. Cuzser, for the appdlants, supported by ties. Coluod and La Pommeraye for the inter-jleaders, against Me. Padoa Bey for tbe de on dan t-widow, Md Me. Lebrohn for the family if Elie de Menasoe. Me. Carton de Wiart was n the oase for Baron James, who, however, lad disposed of most of his rights to Messrs. \gtuon siuoe tbe judgment of first instance. BBALB «. CASSAB. The case of Beale u Cassab came on for searing before tbe Apped Court this morning, rhe Appellant, a Cairo architect was knocked >ff his bicyole in Cairo and seriously hurt by Mr. Cassab’s oarriage. The Native Court oon-lemned Mr. Cassab's ooachmauforbdng on the wrong nde of the street and driving furioaely. Mr. Beale then sued Mr. Cassab for damages, sut tke Cairo tribund, ignoring tbe finding of the Native Coon, nonsuited the plaiutiff on the plea that be must have been ou the wrong side. Mdtre Carton de Wiart appeared for the appellant Mdtre Oddi for Mr. Cassab. Judgment was reserved. FRAUDULENT BANKRUPTCIES. At the a sine sitting was heard the appeal >f three bankrupt merchants called Daoud who iad been condemned to imprisonment for reudulent bankruptcy. Tbe Court had kindly appointed ex officio three of the lesders of the Bsj, Messrs. Padoa Bey, Coluod, and Merdnier, a defend the bankrupts. This kindness was generally supposed to be exoessive on the part >f the Court Judgment on the apped is to w given on tbe 14th inst 8everal cases of damages for accidents kgeiast the Cdro Tramway Company,the Khe-Ihrial Mail Line, the 8tate Rdlways, etc., were ilso heard at this ritting. THE LATE JUDGE GIACCONB This morning, at • o’clock, on the opening >f the ritting of the Court of Apped, the pre-ridSjg judge, Mr. Moriondo, informed his jolleagaes of tbe Beneh and the members of the Bar of the Mixed Court of the death of [Jommendatore Giaooone, for so many years president ol that Court The demise of Com-nendatore Giaooone took plaoeat Florenoe, where tbe lamented judge went to live on bis retirement nine years ago. Judge Moriondo referred feelingly to the eminent qualities of tbe leoeased, who had taken an active part in tbe interaationd conferences extending from 1870 to 1875, when the foundation of the Mixed Court was discussed and tbe oodes prepared. He waa known as a thoroughly reliable jadge, an upright man,and a sound authority in law. As a man, be was admirable in bis private life and ill who approached him became bis friends. He is deeply mourned by his oolleagues. Me. Procureur-Generd Borchgrevink, in the name of tbe Parquet joined in these words ol praise and regret Me. Cuzzer, Batonnierof the Alexandria Bar, round whom were the other members of the Bar Coundl, also spoke in token of the high r^ard in whioh Comm. Giaooone was held, ipedally recalling his gnat kindness to the itafl of the tribunals and to poor litigants. Tbe ritting was then suspended for a quarter of an hour as a sign of mourning. Comm. Giaooone bad lived 25 years in Alexandria, first as consular jadge for Italy, then as councillor, and afterwards president ol the Court of Appeal He was a popular figure ia the Alexandria streets, where he drove or wdked invariably dressed in a black frock ooat and wearing a high bat He had married a lady of the Zogheb family, a great-aunt ol the present generation, and had thus strengthened his connection with the oountry. The tact and what might be odled the diplomatic quditiee,-of the late President often prevented during the “dghties'’seriooe friction between tbe authority of the Government and the Courts. In those days many question! relating to the management of the Guanoes ol the tribunals, eta, bad not been settled and were open to discussion. About 1889 Comm. Giaooone bad dreamed of amalgamating in s oertain way the native and mixed tribunals, by submitting thdr decisions to the same Court of Apped, where Europeans wonld have beet in majorityooly in European oases. However, nothing come of the idea. When Comm. Giao oone retired it was snnoucoed that he waa about to be appointed Senator in Italy, but the nomination did not take plaoe. Comm. Giao oone was 84 yean of age ; he was a devoul Roman Catholio. STEAMER MOVEMENTS. The Cunard 8.8. "P^Via” arrived at liver pool yesterday,

div.head: THE AFRICAN PIGMIES. BY DR. ELLIOT SMITH.
div.p: ( Lecture delivered, before Cairo Scientific Society) The recent sojourn in Cairo of six pigmies, brought from the great forest in the Congo State by Colonel Harrison, has afforded many of ns an opportunity of becoming personally acquainted for the first time with the representatives ot a race long known to ns in Cable and what was supposed to be a tradition, probably as old as Egyptian civilisation.' So much curiosity has been aroused by these little people that I thought 1 might be rendering a service to many of you by transmitting some of the information which I have garnered during the last few weeks, by seafdhing through the extensive literature delating to pigmies and by personal observations made on the little people themselves. The party which recently visited Cairo consisted of six parsons, four males and two females.Of these only two, a man and a woman, can be considered to have reached full maturity, i.e., the stftge in which the bones are no louger capable of increasing in the length. As the average height of the party seemed to be abnormally small, when compared with the measurements hitherto recorded for the pigmy people, one was naturally curious to know whether this exceeding smallness of stature might not be partly due to the age of the individuals. The only means 'of estimating age are the examination of the teeth and the state of ossification of the growing bones. The latter, which is by far the more reliable test, is now possible in living people,si uce the introduction of the use of the Rontgen Rays has enablod us to see every detail in the struoture of the bony tissues. By the courtesy of Dr. Milton we were able to make use of this method and obtain a series of skiagrams of the bones of the hands and arms of the pigmies : the exoellent photographs of the bones were taken at the Victoria Nursing Home by Dr. Khayatt. By means of these photographs I found that in only two of the party had the bones of the arm finished growing and that the other four exhibited various stfcges of immaturity. The smallest member of the party is a mere boy, who, even judged by European standards, cannot be more than twelve or most probably eleven years ot age: he is 1.158 metres in height and weighs only 49 pounds. Another youth is probably no more than seventeen years of age and may be one or two years less, and a third is not much, if at all older, his age limit being about eighteen. The lounger of the two women is probably less than twenty years of age. When it is remembered that all these standards of age are based upon European standards, which there is reason to believe are probably higher than the African, the ages of these four individuals may possibly be even less than the figures that I have given. Taking these facta into consideration it is not surprising to find that the average height (1.305 metres) of the six individuals is considerably less than that (1.452 metres) given by Sir Harry Johnston for the Bambute pigmies. But even the two fully-grown individuals are considerably smaller (the man is 1.367 metres and the woman 1.286 metres), not only than Sir Harry Johnston’s average,but also than the smallest adult man and woman respectively measured by him. All this points to the fact that even the two fully-grown members of the party are small, even for pigmies. This opinion is further strengthened by the fact that one of the immature youths is slightly taller than the fully-grown man, and 'the younger woman, whose bonas are still oapable of growing, is considerably taller (1.334 metres) than the older woman. At the same time it is only just to add that the measurements of even smaller adult pigmies than those we hava seen hjwe been recorded by Sir W. Flower. It is perhaps natural that one engaged in selecting representatives of a small race to bring to Europe would hardly choose the bigger individuals. I have made these preliminary remarks to emphasise the necessity of exercising considerable caution in drawing conclusions as to the size and characters of a race from a few individuals who have been selected, «r who have eleoted to become temporary exiles from their home. It is not infrequently supposed that this is the first visit of pigmies to Egypt (or Europe), but this idea is quite erroneous. These little people had been preceded by several parties of their kinsmen within recent years and probably by more numerous representatives of their race in ancient times. Professor Schweinfurth discovered (or rather re-discovered after a lapse of two centuries) the Akka pigmies in the Monbnttu country in 1870 and obtained from Mouza (King of the Monbnttu) an Akka boy in exchange for a dog. This boy died at Berber on his way to Egypt as the result, so professor Schweinfurth tells me, of an expensive meal of macaroni. Although several travellers are said to have brought pigmies to Europe before his time, the Italian traveller Miani is the first of whom I can find any authentic record, who has been the means of sending genuine pigmies to Europe. He followed the footsteps of Dr. Schweinfurth into the Monbnttu country in 1872 and obtained tw) Akka boyp with the view of bringing tiiem to Europe. Miani himself succumbed to the climate, and at his death left his collections, including the young Akkas, to the Italian Geographical Society. From the contemporary accounts of the treatment to which these unfortunate boys were subjected, we gather that history is merely repeating itself at the present moment in the case of this party of six, for we read that “probably no two individuals of a savage race have ever beta so mtfob bonortd by the attentions of the soientifio

world. First in Cairo,and afterwards in Europe, these two boys were described, measured, and photographed, and have become the .sutyeotp. of a whole library of memoirs, their bibliographers inoluding SirKicbard^Owap in England, Panceri, Cornalia, Mantegazza, Giglioni and Zanetti iu Italy, and Brooa, Hamy and^ de Quatrefages in France” (Sir W. Flower). From the acoounts of Schweinfurth and Sir W. Flower we learn that they were introduced to the King and Queen of Italy and into the most aristocratic society, and that finally they settled down §3 pages in the household of Count Miniscalchi at Verona, after receiving a European education. Oee of them died of phthisis in Verona in 1883 and was buried there without being submitted to any scientific examination. The fate of Jthe other boy I have bean unable to determine, llomolo Gessi (one of Gordon’s lieutenants) took an Akka girl to Europe and she was living at Trieste as a servant to Madame Gessi in 1888, whioh is the latest record I have been able to obtain of her. The fact that some of the pigmy people now live in dose proximity to the sources of the Nile and, according to most anthropologists who have studied the question, probably extended over a muoh wider area formerly, renders it highly probable that at various times the ^ancient dwellers on the banks of the Nile must have heard of or perhaps seen some of these little people in the course of*their numerous expeditions to the south. Bat eyen if this fact were established with absolute certainty it would not justify us in concluding, as so many reoent writers have done, that every mention of small men in the ancient Egyptian writings referred to real pigmies. On the contrary we know for certain that at all times up to to day, true dwarfs, such as occm sporadically in all races of mankind, have been well received and have been given posts ol honor at the court of the ruler of the oountry, For every population there*is a wide range of variation in the stature of individuals, and it frequently happens that, as the result of various pathologioal conditions, growth may oease at an abnormally early period of life. This “dwarfishness” or uanism may be totals in whioh case the whole bod$>is affected, everj part being proportionally reduced in size, sc that the relative sizes are those of a norma! adult; or it may be partial, some parts being small whereas others grow to their full adult dimensions. The result of this partial nanism is often a grossly mis-shapen and distorted body. It is this type of dwarf which is repre sented in the wall-pictures and statues by ancient Egyptian*. As an example of this see the statue of the dwarf Khuumhotpu iu the Museum of Antiquities. Professor Maspero tells me that a careful study of all the passages in Egyptian literature which have been supposed to refer to pigmies, fails to reveal a single example of a description which can certainly justify such a belief. The determinative invariably applied to these so-called pigmies is a hieroglyphic sign representing the mis-shapen figure expressive of partial nanism. Probably the earliest references to one of those doubtful personages is that found in Professor Schiaparelli’s description of an Egyptian tomb (published in 1893). Somewhere near the laud of Egypt was the far-famed land of Punc’a term which has received numerous geographical definitions. •'All that lay beyond Punt was held to be a fabulous region, a kind of intermediate boundary land between the world of men and that of the gods, the ‘Island of the Double,’ ‘Land of Shades.’ It was inhabited by the Dangas, tribes of half-savage (pigmies) whose grotesque faces aud wild gestures reminded the Egyptians of the God /Bes.” In this quotation from Professor Maspero’s ‘Dawn of Civilisation” 1 have substituted the word "pigmies for “dwarfs” because the latter worse in the sense defined above cannot be applied to a tribe, but only to occasional individuals in any given tribe. To continue the quotation : “The chances of war or trade brought some of them from time to time to Punt or among the Amiamti (f.near Wady Haifa): the merchant who suooeeded in acquiring, or bringing them to Egypt] had his fortune made. Pharoah valued the Dangas highly and was anxious to have some of them at any price among the dwarfs with whom he loved to be surrounded:: no knew better than they the dan^r of the goi —that to whioh he unreservedly gave way in his merry moments.” (In regard to this it is instructive to refer to Sir Harry Johnston’s account of the dances of the Bam-bite pigmies [Uganda Projteotorate II. p. 45..] which seem quite appropriate to devotees ol Bes). “Towards the end of his reign King Assi (5th dynasty) prooured one whioh a certain Biurdidi had purchased in Punt. Was this the first which had made its appear ance at court or had others preceded it in the good graoes of the Pnaroahs I His wildness and aotivity and the extraordinary positions whioh he assumed, made a lively impression upon the courtiers of the time, and nearly a century later there were still reminiscences of him” (Maspero, op. cit. pp. 397 and 398). V Professor Keane, quoting from the same memoir of Schiaparelli’s, says that some seventy years after King Assi, “an officer, Heru-Khuf,was sent by Pepi II. (6th Dynasty) to briug back a pigmy alive aud in good heath, from the la d of great trees away to the south.” “That the Danga came from the south we know from a later inscription at Karnak, and that the word meant dwarf is dear from the accompanying determinative of a short person of stunted growth” (“Man, Past and Present,” page 118). Professor Maspero says that the determinative shows that a dwarf and not a pigmy is meant; but we cannot have a race of dwarfs; nor again, if! this Danga was so highly estimated, plaoed

) I A 4 U f 'among the dwarfs,” and remembered for nearly 1 century, it could not have been an ordinary lfarf. Dwarfs are so common in every population, and certainly riot less so 4n Egypt, that one is inolined to the opinion that these remarks cannot apply to a mere dwarf but to a real pigmy.) It is > not at all unlikely that the same determinative, derived from the commonest form -of small person—a partial dwarf of distorted form—may have been applied indiscriminately to- all kinds,, of.dwarfa and pigmies. Otherwise it is impossible to explain the reference to a “tribe” of Dangas. But Pro: fossor Maspero makes the. farther and more serious.objection that .the time allowed for all these early Egyptian expeditions to obtain “dwarfs”: or “pigmies,” whichever it may have been, was not nearly sufficient to permit them thi reach to land where pigmies are now found. He estimates that the time oocupied in these journeys would not have permitted them to have gone further- south than Suakin or thereabouts, it this is so the territory occupied by the pigmiesjnust have extended much farther north than it does at present, or, as the only other alternative, Sehiaparelli’s account of the Dangas is meaningless In a very circumstantial and marvellously accurate aocount of a journey to the Jland of the dwarfs given by Herodotus, the actual dwarf land is described as being on the banks of a river flowing from west to east. The pre sident of our sooiety* Mr. QrW^.tells me that the only region with geographical features snob Herodotus describes is that near the Sobat, whioh is the only important river flowing from west to east in this region. If the province oi thepigmies was as far . extended from theii present domain as the Sobat River in the time of Herodotus, it is quite possible that in the remote period of the time of the 5th dynaaty, it may have reaohed so far north as to have come within the range of the expeditions tc which I have referred. Although the mattei is still very obscure it seems to me that the balance of evidence strongly inclines to the oonclusion that true pigmies came to Egypl quite early at the dawn of the historic period. In the temple of Queen Hataqu at Deir el Bahan there is a pictorial representation of an expedition to the mysterious southern land it which the celebrated picture of the so-called “Princess of Punt” occurs. She is %, short, un-haplly^teatopygous woman, whose rolls of fat %re grossly caricatured. It is impossible tc draw any certain conclusion from this picture as to the exact physical characters of the woman, but the form of her body, the absence of the conventional mode of representing dwarfiihnes8, and her place of origin, will tend to strengthen the belief that real pigmies, exhibiting a tendency to steatopygia, came tc Egypt in these early times from the southern lauds. Professor Kollman of Basle would have us believe that Afrioan pigmies made their way ^ prehistoric times as lar north as the shores of the Mediterranean, and even crossed into Europe with the taller peoples to leave theii ibones in the neolithic graves of Switzerland and Saruthern Europe. But I have frequently found among normal-sized Egyptians’ remains of all ages, numerous diminutive bodies of the same (Egyptian) type, many of them no bigger than the ordinary pigmy. Suoh dwarfed individuals ocour in all raoes, and their presence cannot be regarded as evidence of the existence of the true Negritoes either in Egypt or Europe lin former times, because the physical features of thele small individuals are not those of the Central African pigmies. Everybody has heard of the pigmies of Homer, Aristotle, Herodotus, Ctesias, Pliny, Pomponios Melo, and othei Greek and Latin classical writers. If we are still hestitating before deciding whether the early Egyptian scribes were acquainted with the trne pigmies, there, is no room for suoh doubts in the case of several of these early European writers. If Homer’s fables of the Cranes and pigmies are not very oonvincing, there is the definite statement of Eraatosthanes, a philosopher who lived in the third centary before the Christian era—“The Cranes migrate as far as the lakes beyond Egypt where the Nile has its souroe* There dwell the pigmies. This is no fable : it is the simple truth” (Lady , Amherst’s “Sketch of. Egyptian History”). The combats between the Cranes and the pigmies, were a frequent theme of the Later classical writers and are often depicted on Greek vases. Sir Wm. Flower .describes one of these piotures “from a vase in the Hope oolleotion at Deepdene in whioh the pigmies are shown as dwarfish looking men, with large heads, negro-features, and close woolly or frizzly hair.” Aristotle places the pigmies in Africa near the sources of the Nile. Sir William Flower jays that the account given by Herodotus [Book II. 32, Rawlin’s translation, p. 47) is so sircumstantial and obviously true that it is worth quoting in foil:— “I did hear, indeed, what I will now relate, from certain natives of Oyrene. .Once upon a time, they said, they were on a visit to the oraoular shrine of Ammon, when it ch^ao^that, in the oourse of conversation with Etearohus, the Ammonian King, the talk fell upon the Nile, how that its sources were unknown to all men ! Etrearohus, npon this, mentioned that some Nasmonians had once some to his court and, when a3ked if they jould give any information concerning the uninhabited parts of Libya, had told me the [oliowing tale:— They said there had grown up among them certain wild young men, the jons of certain chiefs, wno, when they came bo man’s estate, indulged in all manner of Bxtravagancies, and among other things drew lots for five of their number to go and explore She desert parts of Libya and try if they could penetrate further than any had previously lone. The young man, therefore, despatched >n this errand by t£eir comrades with A plentiful supply of water and provision* travelled at irst through the uninhabited region, passing

through whioh they came to the wild beast track, when they finally entered upon the desert, which they proceded to cross in a direction from eastco west. After journeying for many days over a wide extent of sand, they came at last to a plain, where they observed trees growing ; approaching them, and seeing fruit on them, they proceeded to gather it While they were thus engaged, there oame upon them some dwarfish men under’the middle height, who seized them and carried them off. The Nasmonians could not understand a word of their language, nor had they any acquaintance with the language of the Nasmonians. They were led across extensive marshes, and finally C4>m§' to a town, where all the men were of the height “Of their conductors, and blaok oomplexioned. A great river flowed by the town, runningt from west to east and oontaiping crocodiled. As I have already mentioned, Mr. Craig, wlio is familiar with the Upper Nile region, tells me that the Sobat River exaotly fits this description. As to the identity of the people with the. pigmies there oanbe, I think, no doobt whatever. The first reoprd of the existence of pigmies in modern times is oontained m “The Strange Adventures of Andrew Battell of Leigh in Essex,” sent by the Portugal’s prisoner to Angola, who lived there, and in the adjoining regions nearly eighteen years (1589-1607), published in “Purchas his PilgrimeS1’ (1625) :— “To the^orth east of Maui Kesook are a kind oflittip people called Marimbas, whioh are no bigger than Boyes of twelve yews old, but very thioke, and live only upon flesh whioh they kill in the woods with their bows and dafta.” And in a work by Dapper on Lower Ethiopia, published in 1686, a race of dwarfs, whioh he oalled Bakke-bakke, is described. This is probably the group of Akka dwarfs whioh Schweinfurth rediscovered almost two centuries later. Little attention was paid to these accounts, which were largely discounted at the time as sensational travellers’ tales, and in the succeeding century critical acumen and .the Wider knowledge of the world’s fauna led writers to “explain away” these stories of pigmies as merely .highly-coloured acoounts of various apes and monkeys. But from the year 1861 onwards trayellere in various parts of Equatorial Africa began once more to record accounts which they had heard of diminutive races of people. Dr. Tonchard (1861) and Admiral Fleuriot de Langle (1868) recorded the rapid extinction of a pigmy race in the Gaboon. M. du Chaillu (1867) gave an acootint of pigmies which he saw iu Ashango-land, between the Gaboon and Congo rivers. But perhaps attention was first rivetted on the existence ol pigmies in modern times by Stanley’s narrative of his journey near the great bead of the Congo, where he heard of the pigmy raoes of Watwas. (“Through the Dark Continent”). In 1887 Dr. Wolff’ gave an account of these Watwas people : he said that they were “Oi lighter colour than the Negroes and never exceed 1.40 metres (4ft. 7ins.) high, but their average height is not more than 1.30 metres (4ft. 3ins.).”^Sir Wm. Flower). The moat noteworthy recent work on the . pigmy people is the late Sir Wm. Flower’s memoir on two Akka skeletons sent to the British Museum in 1887 by Emin Pasha, and the valuable account of the pigmies given in Sir Harry Johnstou’s “Uganda Protectorate,” which also contains a full aooount of the skeleton of a Bambute pigmy by Dr. F. Shrubsall. This brief summary (whioh is taken to a large extent from the writings of Professor Sohweinfurth and,Sir William Flower) mentions only the chief landmarks in the history of our fluctuating knowledge of these little people. To have given a mere list of tbe titles of the memoirs whioh have been written on this subject would have taken np more time than I am allowed for my whole disoourse. Whole treatises, such as that of de Quatre- fages, have been devoted wholly to the dis- cussion of the literature. I need no; spend any more time in discussing the geographical distribution of pigmy races, except to remind you that Equatorial Africa is not the only habitat of these diminutive people. There are pigmy race* in- the Malay Peninsula, the Pbillipine Islands, ifc. Java ^and New Guinea, whioh preeemt a relationship to the eastern branch > f the Negro race analogous to that of thq. Congo pigmies to the African negroes. Midway between the East Asiatic and the African groups there is a. race of pigmies in the Andaman Islands. The Veddahs of Ceylon and the pigmy races of India fall into another group, for they do not possess those peculiarly distinctive features which have led to the inolusion of all other pigmies in one group called Negritoes. In Africa there are two (or perhaps it is more correct to say three) pigmy races. There is the peculiar group of bushmen in South Africa, the Hottentot—a blend of Bushmen and Bandu-speaking negroes,—and finally in Equatorial Africa extending three degrees north and south of the equator, containing the pigmy tribe to which the people we are studying belong. Xhqy are p^bably the smallest existing race of human beings. I need not spend muoh time in,describing their physic characteristics, because the lantern slides aud photographs which you have seen have all theso features plain. I would especially call attention to the great projection of the jaws ; the excessive flattening of the nose whioh is carried to such an extent that the lateral wings are sometimes fully as large as the central part; the vertical bulging (bombd) forehead; and the peppercorn arrangement of the short, olosely ourled hair. All these features are oharacteristio of negpes, but in the pigmies they are all carried Jo an extreme degree—are in fact ultranegroidp. The ohooo-late brown oolour of their skin if lighter than that of many negroes, but, as thiie six indivi- ' duals demonstrate, there is a considerable range of variation in ooloar. I think that far too muon has been made of the '* difference in

colour between * pigmies and negroes : many npgroes, even when unmjxed with Hamitic ox Semitic blood, are exactly the same colour as these six individuals, and it it were not for their small stature they unite realily pass as pure negroes. The colour difference has been unduly emphasised as the result of the hasty comparisons ipstituted by many writer* between tins yellow skinned bushmen and the pigmies. There are in fact many strikii 0 point! ol resemblance. Both races are obviously related to the truo' negroes ; both are of short stature have e.xceptionally flat noses, vertical forcheadi and “peppercorn” hair. In many structural details there is a close similarity between the two races. One of the main objections whicfc some writers have raised against this view if the fact that steatopygia, which is suoh ^ strikingly bizarre an i characteristic feature ol the bushwomen, is not found in the pigmj women. There has been great oonfliot of opi nion on this subject. Many writers have cate gorically stated that steatopygia never 0court in pigmies, but many recent writers (see De niker’s “Races ot Mankind”) admit that il may ocour. The younger of the two women in Qol. Harrison’s party exhibits this feature quite distinctly. There is apparently a distinci colour difference between the bushmen and the pigmies,'yet from the accounts given bj travellers there must be a very wide range 0 Variation am6ng “the latteit1, and, if %e acoepi j)u Chaillu’s statements regarding the light brown pigmies of Ashiraiand, there must be almost a gradual transition from the dee{ chooolate brown tint of most pigmies to the fellow of the bushman. Apart from the differ ences in colour and size, there am>obvious dis tinotions in the form of the eyes and non when bushman and negrillo are compared Time does not permit me to enter into a fuli disoussion of this diffioult problem : but a study of the data at our disposal seems to point clearly to the fact that the bushmen anc the negrillo are the diversely specialised remnants of a primitive negro-stbek which al one time inhabited the greater part of Africa, from which they were driven by their biggei brothers and took refuge—the bushmen in the desert lands of South-West Africa and th( pigmies in the dense forests of Equatoria Africa. It seems probable that the true negrc element has been considerably strengthened ir the pigmies by intermixture with the surround ing tribes. One of the four males—the biggesl of the four—has a much more pronouncec negro likeness than the others and one of the woman presents a facial type totally unlike the others in most respects—a face suggestive rather of the type so common in Abyssinia where the Hamitic element enters largely intc the constitution of the people. It is probable therefore that we have to deal with a race by bo means pure, but extremely intermixed with isurrounding peoples. It is commonly supposed that the pigmy jpeople are much more ape-like than most other human beings, but there is little real evidence jin support of this supposition. The lips of the Jtypidal pigmy present a striking resemblance to those of the anthropoid apes. This is espe cially marked whilst drinking: the lips are thee pouted irk a trumpet like-manner, just as in the chimpanzee. The lips are not “fleshy” and everted as in the true nej§ro, but markedly elongated and thin. The ears are relatively sis small and. often as well moulded as those oi a European. The pendant part of the ear,which anatomists call the lobule, is absent in the apes and is very small in two of the six pigmies. Much has been written about the hairy covering of the body in pigmies but, with the possible exoeption of the boy of the party, who has perhaps a rather abundant downy oovering, these pigmies have no more trace of a “Simian ooat” than the average European. The separation of the great toe from the others is no more marked than it is in most negroes, and the power of grasping with their toes is no greater than that of the fellah or other native who habitually goes barefooted. The head, which is shorter than that of most negroes, is also proportionately small. Apart from the skeleton no observations have ever been published regarding the internal structure of the body. About frwo years ago there came to the Anatomical DepHrtm6iit of the School of Medioine, the bodies of two very‘ 8mall blaok women (otie was 1.436 metres in height, the other a few millimetres less) of unknown prbvendnoe; they presented none of the mutilations winch the bodies of most Sudanese woman present and the proportions of their limbs and bones, the form of their heads and faces, were those of pigmies. Th^y were exceptionally rich m structural peculiaritieis of a retrograde type, suoh as are quite rare in ordinary human beings. Their brains were exbeptiohally small: the old womanv (about 4(7 years) had a brain of only 850 grammes, and the ydunger woman’s (22 years) brain was 920 grammes. The average weight of an Egyptian woman’s brain is 1,180 and the European woman’s is perhaps more' than 100 grammes heavier A gorillas brain may weigh more than 50 grammes and the so-called intermediate liu! betwa# man and the apes—the fossil Pitbe cantlfroyus, had a brain of the Sima aizj a the elder of these two women. These figures, although undoubtedly ol groat significance, aflb somewhat discounted by the fiact that, other things baing equ d, a small person has a smaller brain than -« large individual. Apart from their size tb m brains were no more simian than the ordin .rj negro's. To sum up, tSe pigmy peop'e 0 Equatorial Africa are in most respects a ray of ultranegroid type, which i3 in mo3t respect: no more ape-like than the ordinary negro. A BOX-AtAKEtt’a CURE. div.head: CAIRO MODEL WORKSHOPS. (From our Oaiko Correspondent).
div.p: On Saturday last I paid a visit to the Cairo Model Workshops which are situated in Boulac, and owing to the courtesy of Johnson i'ttsha 1 was able to examine the excellent work which is being carried ont here under his: direction. It appeared to me that a want which has long been telt by the residents in Egypt is .ore being supplied, for the yonng native undergoes in these works a most careful : raining in many branches of workmanship and cannot tail to become an expert and . thorough workinau in whichever of these branches his taste or adaptability may decide him to adopt. It is an almost everyday complaint in Eg^pt that ordinary work as done by the native, such as joinery, iron-work, saddlery, decoration, and such-like, *is done in a slip-shod manner by men who do not understand the rudiments of the work which they are undertaking, and that, as long as the work is completed with apparently good results, the durability is of but little account; ami such complaints are certainly not ground-le^.-Tbe method of teaching, however, which is adopted in the Model Workshops, puts aside all possibility of the work done by any of their pupils being anything but thorough, tur the tirst principle which is here inculcated iuto the minds of the young workman is that he must thoroughly understand the most minute details of the work upon which heJs engaged. There is no elaborate system of lectures, the worst form of teaching a young mind the theory upon which practice is based ; a piece of work is set before a boy and as he carries it oat the practical utility of each step is carefully demonstrated to him. Practice is not taught by theory, but theory is illustrated by practice. The engineering department is perhaps the best example to take of the thoroughness with which the work is done, as being that in whioh the greatest care must be paid to details and in which accuracy and a minute knowledge of the various steps which are to be gone through arc essential. Models are set before the pupil of various portions ol machinery for him to draw, and alter be has succeeded in making an accurate drawing of these parts he then has to draw them in transverse, vertical, horizontal, obiijue, and every other form of section, and it cau readily be understood that this cannot be (tone unless the subject has been most thoroughly mastered, it was quite a revelation to me to see vlith what accuracy these drawings were made, and the excellent plans of various complicated pieces of machinery which had oeen drawn by these boys* in the department where decoration is taught i marvelled, too, at the designs which boys of tweive and thirteen years of age were able to reproduce faultlessly, and was glad to see that they are being taught to use their right and left hand alike in the making of these drawings. In this department 1 saw various designs for wall-decoration which had been painted by the boys and others, in the course of completion, both in Oriental and European styles, and stencilling, too, formed a part of their education. Furniture of every description abounded in the shops where woodwork is taught, and was such as to make me envious to possess much cf it. The fancy work done in brass.silver, and oop-per was excellent, and though done by youths of tender age no fault could be found with either the workmanship or the design. The commoner objects of practical utility, such as water-cans, pails, etc., appeared to be of a a st durable kind,and I also saw both a lady’s and gentleman’s bicycle which had been made by these pupils, and which would compare favorably with those turned oat by well-known firms. 1 must not omit to mention the saddlery department, where the work which is done can be relied upon to the same extent as that done by the other departments, or to the foundry, which has recently been added, and which, though only a small one, has proved of great advantage to the pupil-engineers. In conclusion, let me say that these work-shi -pB are not only worth a visit to see the work which is being tarried out in them, but that they are deserving of being encouraged by the public purchasing the various articles which they turn-out and in which the purchaser will not be disappointed. Lord Cromer, in referring to these workshops, says In 19U4, the expenditure amounted to L.E. 8,200. The receipts—including L.E. 1,000 due for work in course of progress, but not yet paid for -amounted to L.E, 3,500. There can be no objection tO' the workshop executing private orders, provided the prioes charged are ' t such as to compete unfairly with the various trades, fiut it is essential that, in framing the organisation, the commercial should not be allowed to predominate over the industrial side of the system. So long as the Government grant was only just sufficient to maintain the workshop, there was a manifest ri>k that this danger would he incurred. The Government grant has been increased by about L.E. 1,300. The workshop will only, in case o necessity, re draw its receipts from the Trea feury. It cannot be too clearly urtierstood thai the main object which the Government seek* to attain, in creating this and similar institutions, is not to make money, but to afford such instruction as will enable the pupils to become hkiiled artisans, and to gain their livelihood in after life. Another point of importance calls for some remarks. The basis of the system of instruc tion inaugurated at the workshop is that, the education of artisans, practice should be allowed to predominate over theory. Daring the first year of attendance, there was no di$oalty in enforcing this principle , the work

of the-pupils had, of necessity, to be mainly manual Even if they had understood theory, they would not have been in a position to apply it. But in 1904, when the institution entered upon the second year of its existence, an active demand appears to have arisen amongst the pupils themselves for more theoretical, and less practical, teaching. This was manifested more particularly amongst those who were engaged in metal work, which consists largely m making the component parts of engines. It is true that every moderately competent fitter in Egypt is likely to fiud himself, sooner or later, in charge of an engine of some sort, for the supply of engine hands in the country cannot, for a long time to come, keep pace with the demand. But Johnson Pasha very truly remarks : “As the raison d'etre of the workshops is to create artisans, properly so called, and not engineers, it is absolutely necessary to refrain from much theoretical instruction until a considerable degree of manual skill has been attained.” This institution has to contend with a difficulty which is generally encountered in this country whenever professional or technical instruction is afforded. Directly the pupils have acquired a sufficient amount of skill or knowledge to enable them to gain ever so small a wage, they are incliued to abandon the course of instruction. “There has been some necessity,” Johnson Pasha writes, "to put pressure on parents and guardians to insure regular attendance ; boys supposed to be sick have been found to be earning wages outside.” Mohamed Suleiman Pasha, owing to whose liberality and publio spirit an industrial school had been established at Abou-Tig, has drawn attention to the same difficulty as that encountered ^y Johnson Pasha at Cairo : the boys will not stay long enough at the school to acquire thorough profioienoy in their various crafts. Johnson Pasha, however, says that the tendency to abandon the course of training prematurely, “diminishes as the boys grow older, and come gradually to appreciate the value of the training they receive." Both Mohamed Suleiman Pasha and Johnson Pasha have suggested that, in order to check this tendency, it might be as well to exempt from military service those boys who receive a satisfactory certificate after having completed the whole course of training. The Recruiting Law will probably have to be recast before long. When this is done it would appear that this suggestion is well worthy of consideration. SPOUT AND PL\Y. ALEXANDRIA.SPOTTING CLUB. div.head: ABINET.
div.p: The faot that the thinking has to be done by individuals leads, in the oase of all Parliaments, to the existenoe of a number of persons called Ministers, who either do the thinking or.get it done for them by other individuals of greater intelligence (writes Sir Martin Cbnway in the “Nineteenth Century”). The offioial thinkers, meeting together, form the Cabinet or Council of Ministers, or whatever it may be called. Every crowd has to have suoh a council, as a olub or sooiety has to have an executive committee. Now, if this council does not exceed in number the maximum which can meet round a table, each person present having the opportunity to speak in a conversational manner whilst all can hear, it will fulfil its purpose as a orowd-brain ; but if the numbers exceed that limit your exeoutive committee or cabinet will forthwith in turn become a orowd incapable of deliberation, and itself dependent again upon some individual or individuals to think for it This is exactly what has happened in reoent days with the English Cabinet A century ago its numbers were small enough for the individuality of each member to be maintained, and the personalities of each and all of them to have effeot But now the Cabinet is so large that this is no longer possible. It is a little crowd,,possessed, therefor^ ofaU theorowd-characteriatics* chief amQqgstwhich is, the desire for power and an instinctive hostility to all other orowds. Fundamentally, the Cabinet is hostile to the House of Commons. It continuously strives, and with sucoees, to appropriate to itself the powers whioh properly belong to the House of Commons. It supplants the House of Commons as a deliberative assembly; it has praotioally taken away from it the power of refusing supplies, or of debating whatever subjects it pleases; in fact in the course of a oentury, it has wrought an absolute revolution in our whole constitutional system. Nothing but the phrases remain—the facts are all changed. HELLENISM IN EGYPT. The . Greek element is very strong in the oommeroe or Egypt, as we have already observed, but it is not perhaps generally recognised that it is the Greeks who carry on the retail trade of the Nile Valley, and who penetrate even to the smallest villages. They sell articles of food whioh oome from abroad, and really do a great deal toward# helping to civilise the Sudanese tribes. After the battle of Omdurman Greek traders followed in the track of Krtohener’s army/ and spread to El Obekl and into Kordofan, where they found and reported traoes of many of the victims who were massacred when Mr. Gladstone handed over the Upper Nile to barbarism. They have crossed Afrioa from Lake Albert Nyanza to the Zambesi and the Congo; but what is most remarkable about tjkttae men is that they can turn their handj to kny-thing, and become agriculturists or hotelkeepers with equal facility in the straigest plaoes, if they see their profit The Government of Egypt has acknowledged the service the Greek traders are doing as pioneers in opening up the oountry, and, for their |>art, the Greeks recognise that they owe everything to the Government, which, by restoring peace and law, has made it possible for trade and commerce to be carried on in the interior of Africa. It will be as well to keep an eye on these wandering traders, £>r their knowledge of what is going on in the most distant places should be of service in ascertaining the actual trend of native thought among the Sudanese.^-(From “The Globe.”)
A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.

This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs au sud de l'ancien cimetière israélite jusqu’au fort el Nahas.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 18 courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L’enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: “Soumission pour les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs.”

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d’une banque, d’après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 18 courant à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 7 juillet 1905.

div.head: CHRONIQUE J UDICIAIRE V 00UR D’APPEL MIXTE
div.p: JEU DE BOUK.SE ET SPECULATION La dame Cavafy avait actionn^ Petrooc-kinos en paiement de £ 210 en vertu de deux reconnaissances, dont Petrocokinos ne con-teatait pas la'signature, mais qn’il refuaait de payer boos pretexts quo oette dette provenaif de pertea subies en sp^culant k la Bourse et qo’etant simple employe de 8 livres par moiB et n’ayant pas d’autre ressource personnelle, il s’agissait d’un jeu prohibit p4r la loi. Le tribunal en a juge differemment et prononce qu’en l’espoce il ue s’agissait pas d’un simple jeu ou pari sur lea fluctuations dea cours, mais d’une operation sdrieuse, comme il rdaulte de la coi-reapondance echangtSe entre parties. l’etrocokinoa ay ant fait appel de cejuge* ment, la Cour dans son audience de ce matin conirme purement et simplement la sentence des premiers jugea. Lea principaux motifs invoqofe par la Cour sont qu’aucune disposition de la loi egyptienne n’anaalle les marches and terme. Pour que de tela marches puiasent tit re annuls, il faut qu’il y ait eu des manoeuvres doloaives de la part du courtier; ce qui n’est pas le cas en l’esp£ce. L’Affaire de la Cie du Canal de Suez Nous lisons -dans les dcrniers joumaux de Paris: “ M. Charles de Lessepa a ete entendu, bier, par M. le juge Leydet. II s’eat plaint d’avoir ete, depuis trop longtemps, en butte aux menaces de M. Paulin Sylvan, avocat au Cairo, qui en veut k 8a vie. “ M. PanHn Sylvan continue n pr5tendre que la premiere liste des fondateurs de la Compagnie du Canal de Suez a ete modifide et que des noma ont ete supprim^s. De ce fait, plusieurs personnes auraient ete lda^ea dans lenrs interfits. L’avocat du Caire avait envoys, dans ce sens, k la Chambre des deputes, une petition qui a 616 rejetee. “ M. de Lesseps a apporte au magistrat inatructeur des documents pour rdduire k ndant les assertions de son trop vindicatif adversaire.” M. Paulin Sylvan eat connu au Cairo ou il 86 trouvait il y a quatre ana avant de rentrer k Paris. On lui doit m§me plusiers articles 8ur la Compagnie du Canal publics dans la prease locale. Une demarohe de la Ohambre de oommeroe La Chambre de commerce international a ecrit au ministere des Finances pour lui recommander le vucu le l’Union des entrepreneurs, qui demandent que lbraque des oppositions sont faitea par dea tiers au paiement du rnon-tant de travaux executes pour le oompte du gouvernement, celui-ci ne retienne que la som-me auffisante k satisfairo eventuellement l’op-posant et a se liberer du surplus, au lieu de la pratique courante d’apris laquelle, pour une saisie minime, on retarde le paiement de som-mes importantes. _'i v Les chemins de fer et la navigatu n Un de nos confreres indigenes assure qu’un arrangement serait intervenu entre l’adminie-tration des chemins de fer et la Compagnie de Kom-Ombo, d’aprfca lequel la promise accorde-rait k l’antre prdcit^e, pendant une periode de vingt anst une reduction de 25% 8ur le prix de transport, k la oondition que tous les transports de la Societe soient effectors par chemin de fer. DELEGATION MUNICIPALE (Communication OJfttielle ) La Delegation Municipale s’est r^unie le 6 join 1905 k5 h. p.m. .soua la pr^aidence de Mr. Amb. A. Ralli. Presents : M.M. P. Fenderl, Manaour Bey Yousaef, Soliman Bey Abani, Q. Zervudachi, Dr. Q. Valenain, Dr. Schiess Bey, membiea, W. P. Chataway, administrateur, I. Sedky Bey, secretaire. La Delegation decide de oonfier k M. Agostini la ioumiture de 5000 medailles-plaquea and l’oocasion du rfeglement sur les chiena. Elle emet un avis favorable k un projet eiabord PM le Gouvernement tendant a l’ou-verture durant la nuit des pouts du rmnul Mahmoudieh pour le transit dea bateaux. Cea ponta devront Streouverts ktour de r61e de fa^on k e viter toute interruption entre lea deux rivea du canal en cas d’accident. La Delegation decide la commando k M. Pleach de 100 syphons. Elle prend note du con-sentemant donne par le Gouvernement au projet d’expropriation des echiches du Gabbary et de lenr tranafert dans la looalite avoisinante du Mex.
